creator: haui@haumacher.de
text:
I would like to create zip files, that store executable permissions for some
files. This is possible for tar files by setting the mode attribute in
tarfileset elements. In a simmilar way, the same thing should be possible for
zip files.

see the documentation on java.util.zip.ZipEntry : there is no notion of users 
or permissions in what is really a DOS based format.

Unless you can get some standardised comment/extra data to include perms, 
there is no benefit in supporting it as nothing which unzips a file will 
handle anything that is added to the file.

Marking as a WONTFIX.
creator: steve_l@iseran.com
bodewig@apache.org
text:
But look at the documentation for org.apache.tools.zip.ZipEntry, which is
what Ant uses. 8-)

Inside Zip.java there is code that looks like this

        // this is 040775 | MS-DOS directory flag in reverse byte order
        ze.setExternalAttributes(0x41FD0010L);

i.e. Ant stores the Unix permissions for directories (it ensures that the
execute bit has been set) already inside the external attributes.

The mechanism may not be standardized as such, but Ant uses the same way to
store Unix permissions that InfoZip uses, which in turn is the base for all
Unix zip/unzip implementations I am aware of (and for OpenVMS and WinZip as
well).
This feature is supposed to work starting with nightly build 2002-12-10.
